description: Katz v. United States - reasonable expectation of privacy in phone booth
facts: FBI agents attached electronic listening device to outside of public phone booth
Katz made phone calls from the booth
Katz had closed the door and expected privacy
No physical intrusion into the booth occurred
asp_facts: case(katz). amendment(katz, fourth). surveillance_type(katz, electronic_listening). location(katz, public_phone_booth). warrant_obtained(katz, no). physical_intrusion(katz, no). expectation_of_privacy(katz, yes). privacy_objectively_reasonable(katz, yes). door_closed(katz, yes).
question: Did the warrantless electronic surveillance violate the Fourth Amendment?
rationale: The Fourth Amendment protects people, not places. What a person knowingly exposes to the public is not protected, but what one seeks to preserve as private, even in public, may be constitutionally protected. Katz had a reasonable expectation of privacy in the phone booth, making the warrantless surveillance unconstitutional.
